data.title: Settings are not universal, they are specific to Workspace

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.5.1
- OS Version:Windows7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. File>Preferences
2. There are two options:
   i. The UserSettings are not editable.
   ii.The Workspace settings are editable.

The workspace settings are applied for a particular workspace. 

THERE SHOULD BE AN OPTION TO SAVE THE SETTINGS GLOBALLY.

data.title: Incorrect handling of git commit message template
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.5.1
- OS Version: Linux

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Put a template with file name `.git_commit_msg.txt` in home directory
2. config git to use it globally
3. open vscode, make some change in git project, choose to use vscode git commit functionality
4. Instead of just putting the non-commented part, it fills the entire template in commit message.

```
~ ❯ cat ~/.git_commit_msg.txt 
# If applied, this commit will...


# Explain why this change is being made

# Provide links to any relevant tickets, articles or other resources
```

2. Switch to preview mode

Exptected ist to keep the the second tab and swith "two.md" to preview..

data.title: ShowQuickPick does not fulfil the promises
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

I developed an extension for VSCode and since the newest update (this morning) I've got a serious problem: 

``` typescript
public addImportPick(activeDocument: TextEditor): Thenable<ResolveQuickPickItem> {
    return window.showQuickPick(this.buildQuickPickList(activeDocument));
}
```

`buildQuickPickList` does produce a Promise

When I call showQuickPick in such a manner, the following error occurs:

```
TypeError: e.done is not a function
    at /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/node/extensionHostProcess.js:6:23142
    at new n.Class.derive._oncancel (/Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/node/extensionHostProcess.js:5:26897)
    at f (/Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/node/extensionHostProcess.js:6:23109)
    at Object.h [as wireCancellationToken] (/Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/node/extensionHostProcess.js:6:23050)
    at t.showQuickPick (/Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/node/extensionHostProcess.js:12:14157)
    at Object.I.window.showQuickPick (/Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/node/extensionHostProcess.js:12:30588)
    at ResolveQuickPickProvider.addImportPick (/Users/christoph/Documents/Development/typescript-hero/out/src/provider/ResolveQuickPickProvider.js:29:32)
    at ResolveExtension.addImport (/Users/christoph/Documents/Development/typescript-hero/out/src/extensions/ResolveExtension.js:117:27)
    at /Users/christoph/Documents/Development/typescript-hero/out/src/extensions/ResolveExtension.js:74:143
    at /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/node/extensionHostProcess.js:12:29049
```

Is this caused by the update ?

data.title: Regression: --goto feature should accept empty line and column numbers
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: MacOs

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open terminal
2. run code . --goto somefile: 

Expected: VSCode opens the file.
Actual: throws an error `Arguments in`--goto`mode should be in the format of`FILE(:LINE(:COLUMN))`.`

The reason is simple - iTerm2 can be configured to run a program on a Cmd+click on filename in the terminal. It offers an ability to pass line number if it was identified, but it can't add colon conditionally if it identified the line number or not.

Feature was working on previous version

data.title: Feature Request: Support for Multiple Integrated Terminals
data.body:
It would be great if we were able to open multiple types of integrated terminals (e.g. both bash and PowerShell) in the same session. These could, for instance, be specified as semicolon-delimited paths in the `terminal.integrated.shell.windows` property, and within the terminal window we could launch a new instance either via right-clicking the "+" button, or via a dropdown menu.

Note that this is not a high-priority issue, since there is a workaround: PowerShell can launch cmd.exe and bash (including proper path translation), but it would be nice to have for alternative default terminals and configurations.

data.title: A version mismatch between the globally installed tsc compiler (1.0.3.0) and VS Code's language service (1.8.10) has been detected. This might result in inconsistent compile errors.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start up VSCode
2. Experience the info message "A version mismatch between the globally installed tsc compiler (1.0.3.0) and VS Code's language service (1.8.10) has been detected. This might result in inconsistent compile errors."

I have not directly installed TypeScript globally with npm.  I can only assume this is a result of having Visual Studio 2015 installed on the same machine.  (I think that ships with tsc 1.0.3.0 installed globally?)  I didn't experience this with VSCode 1.4 and below.

Is there a way to prevent this error short of uninstalling Visual Studio 2015?  

The message appears to come from here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/b5a3c7350bdadd3b68a43fc825b4ac50f8ecc7b3/extensions/typescript/src/typescriptServiceClient.ts#L387

Thanks,
John

PS VSCode is awesome!

data.title: Bug in cursor location within user snippets
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.0 & 1.5.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6 (15G1004)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add the following snippet to the javascript.json user snippets file:

``` json
{
     "Print to console": {
        "prefix": "log",
        "body": [
            "console.log('$1');"
        ],
        "description": "Log output to console"
    }
}
```
1. Then open an .js file and type "log" ENTER to insert the snippet.

Before the update of 1.5.0 the cursor appeared at $1 `console.log('|');` now at the end of the line  `console.log('');|`

data.title: Add a Duplicate to the click-menu in the explorer pane
data.body:
Feature request: 

When right/ctrl-clicking on a file in the explorer, it would be helpful to have a Duplicate selection. This would copy and paste the selected file into another new file in the same directory.

My ideal would be to allow for a rename immediately after duplicate; alternatively it would just create the file with the filename-n name.

Currently this can be done with a ctrl-click copy and then a ctrl-click paste in the directory.

data.title: Spurious error: [ts] Duplicate function implementation
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.0-insider `4fc690be310dd02e0ab6529c0b9bf348a8b26a19`
- OS Version: macOS 10.11.6 (15G1004)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. `vscode-insiders .` 
2. Edit `src/big-file.ts`, which is too long and stuffed with unrelated concerns
3. `vscode-insiders -r src/extracted-function.ts`
4. Cut a function out of `src/big-file.ts`
5. Paste it into `src/extracted-function.ts`
6. Observe red underline under the function name
7. Select it
8. Observe error: `[ts] Duplicate function implementation.` 
9. Close `src/extracted-function.ts`
10. Re-open `src/extracted-function.ts`
11. Observe no red underline under the function name

Perhaps unrelated to #9880.

data.title: Cannot use --goto parameter with paths that include a drive letter with a colon :
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1 (07d663dc1bd848161edf4cd4ce30cce410d3d877)
- OS Version: Windows 10 14393.0.160715-1616

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a file with vscode, adding the --goto or -g parameter to navigate to a specific line number. Be sure to include the drive letter with a colon (:) in the path specified

Result: Failure to open file and an error:

```
C:\> code --goto C:\TestFile.txt:12
Arguments in `--goto` mode should be in the format of `FILE(:LINE(:COLUMN))`.
```

Whereas using a relative path that doesn't include the colon:
`C:\> code --goto .\TestFile.txt:12`
 is successful in opening the file.

It looks like commit c2da84de3ae965b4d3b093521c5c37eee94dcd8d caused the issue with a bad regular expression:

```
if (args.goto) {
    args._.forEach(arg => assert(/^[^:]+(:\d+){0,2}$/.test(arg), localize('gotoValidation', "Arguments in `--goto` mode should be in the format of `FILE(:LINE(:COLUMN))`.")));
}
```

data.title: 1.5 Release breaking React ES6
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5 or 1.5.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. using webpack (haven't tried gulp yet) npm start any project that has ES6 code in it and it will break. Same project works fine using Atom.
2. You'll get the module parse failed:  Unexpected token with the line number and You may need an appropriate loader to handle this file type.
   I can go right back to Atom and use the exact same project with the integrated terminal in that program run npm start and everything loads perfectly, all tests, all linting passes, and hot loading starts.

data.title: Treat hyphen as part of word
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1

In some programming languages, especially Lisp-like ones, the hyphen (`-`) is treat as part of a word.
Now when I click or double click a word in VSCode, it is highlighting like this:

![20160909074504](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1673525/18370674/873349be-7661-11e6-81a8-7e0f5dc821ab.png)

What I expect is like this:

![rebol20160909074552](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1673525/18370741/018336e8-7662-11e6-9381-190080dbd6d7.png)

How can I do this in VSCode ?

data.title: Add a setting to reveal a opened file in any window if opening from outside VS Code

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

Sorry for the strange title description there. I'm pretty crap at that :)

Not sure if this is a VSCode plugin issue or with Code itself...

In Split-View, if I have an error in the file in, say, the left view, and the last view I was in was the right one, when I click on the error in the Unity console, the same file will open up in a new tab in the right view, rather than selecting the same opened tab.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use Code in Split View.
2. Open a file (C# Monobehaviour) in the left view (file1.cs), and another in the second view (file2.cs).
3. Create an error in file1.cs, and save. Then switch to file2.cs in the right view.
4. Jump into Unity, and click on the error message in the console.

You'll now see file1.cs open another tab in the right view. Not sure if this is by design, but it would be good to have the option of just selecting the already opened tab. 

To illustrate what I mean...

![player_cs_-_buggyball](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1317345/18370709/45b5866a-7683-11e6-807b-461af4107fc9.png)
